description: grob has conducted mdma research and has written about the political history of the drug he adds that mdma does carry risks such the increased likelihood of high blood pressure reactions and episodes of an inherited condition called malignant hyperthermia but he also says that the emphasis mdma neurotoxicity was distraction away from further exploring genuine risks that users might incur wasn aware of the controversy around mdma research until he left prison he wouldn even know the seismic changes in how studies were conducted and interpreted until he began studying drugs himself upon release enrolled in technical college then still strapped to an ankle monitor transferred to the university of in he was allowed to take classes but was denied campus housing due to his record he was accepted

description: to the mcnair scholars program an initiative that helps minority students transition into doctoral studies programs mcnair scholars receive two things that changed life stipend which gave him financial freedom when he couldn find work and mentor under krista lisdahl neuropsychologist who researches the cognitive impact of adolescent drug use began digging into ecstasy connections to depression using data lisdahl lab had already collected people with history of ecstasy use he found that users showed more depressive symptoms compared to control groups and that users with specific variant of the gene which is associated with psychiatric conditions showed even greater levels of depressive symptoms than users without the variant to these results supported the common belief that ecstasy can impair users by causing severe depressive mood disruptions but his conclusions
label: science

description: changed after finding review paper written by carl hart hart performed an analysis of studies meth cognitive effects when looking at results from brain imaging studies and from cognitive tests that examined things like memory attention and function hart found that control groups often users did better few tests than longtime meth users those differences though real were still within what scientists considered normal range those tests scans suggesting that even after years of using meth people still had normal brain function in spite of these observations there seems to be propensity to interpret any cognitive brain difference clinically significant abnormality hart wrote looked at his own research and found the same problem ecstasy users with specific gene variant had more depressive symptoms than control groups but were still essentially
label: science

description: normal kept seeing hart name and learned that the columbia researcher wasn much different from him hart also sold marijuana teenager after crack appeared in the miami neighborhood where he grew up hart turned to drug research way to warn people about the dangers of drugs time and time again he found that risks existed but were frequently exaggerated drug sentences were far more likely to leave permanent marks when they connected in st louis was embarrassed by his record says hart knew of his mentor so knew that he was doing the work hart says my first impression was what shame that he embarrassed when he doing the best he can wanted to make sure did whatever could to make sure that he realized that his life wasn over
label: science

description: because of mistake applied to columbia and didn make it but was recommended for bridge program that prepares students to transition into phd programs the following winter he found himself huddled around broken space heater in filthy bronx apartment which was the only place he could find that didn require background check he couldn believe he had made it to columbia today all but lives in hart lab he has small remnants of his past like the tiny solitary confinement torture sign his desk but columbia is mostly new world few people there understand the helplessness of watching friends back home get locked up many of them instead have trained all their lives to attend an ivy league college and don understand how hard it was for to try to
label: science

description: catch up following hart lead is determined not to repeat mistakes of the past much of the last years of mdma research challenges the initial neurotoxicity reports of the and early while studies have consistently shown that mdma can potentially damage serotonin cells later studies have contested the links between mdma use and problems with memory and brain function one study found that mdma can alleviate some parkinson symptoms for people who are low in specific brain chemical called dopamine small mountain of emerging research suggests possibilities for positive uses in psychotherapy nonprofit research and advocacy group called maps is currently testing mdma ptsd treatment their work has progressed to phase three clinical trial which is generally the final phase of testing before drug treatment protocol gains fda approval even
label: science

description: the field improves there evidence that methodological concerns about existing research remain one review that looked at mdma studies some published late and found that definitions of heavy versus light users varied so much between studies that heavy users in one study would have been considered light users in another making it unacceptably easy for researchers to report significant findings where no relationship exists separate review by the same author noted that current and past mdma research is further limited by studies that gather data from participants who use street ecstasy which often contains little no mdma the review also found that statistical errors biases and methodological problems were so pervasive in the field that despite wealth of studies that point to mdma causing brain damage the available data can
label: science

description: only suggest an association rather than causal relationship between mdma use and neurocognitive deficits several mdma researchers interviewed for this story said that in general scientists now are far more deliberate about careful study design and methodologies but comprehensively understanding the effects of the drug requires testing it in humans and hart are part of small group of scientists who are focusing human ecology the amounts and circumstances under which users actually take drugs though hart sometimes collaborates with researchers who study drug effects in animals his team only studies human subjects which requires overcoming enormous regulatory and infrastructure hurdles including obtaining dea license and recruiting physicians and psychologists to ensure that research is conducted ethically and participants aren subjected to unreasonable harm under that umbrella of ecological relevance is
label: science

description: currently investigating two gaps in the scientific literature how amphetamines interact with other drugs since users often don stick to just one and the effects of repeated mdma dosing this work is slow and expensive experiments require finding participants who have no psychiatric disorders substance abuse issues physical conditions and who can pass an psychiatric interview and physical examination there hope that proving therapeutic use could lead to mdma being removed from schedule and potentially decriminalized that doesn help those who are currently struggling to move past drug convictions wants pardon hope catalyzed by wisconsin gov tony evers recent move to grant clemency to someone else who was convicted of selling ecstasy at age he also wants to help other formerly incarcerated people find the same pathways into science that
label: science

description: carl hart made possible in the formerly incarcerated research and science training first program an initiative that helps recently released enter science graduate programs and conduct research the roughly program covers basics like conducting literature review and applying to grad school it also provides participants with mentoring career development and stipend the challenges for first participants are enormous some spent decades in prison and are attempting to scale academia while transitioning into the mainstream facing employment barriers and adjusting to using basic technologies like cellphones and tablets still the program shows promise out of the five formerly incarcerated graduates in first inaugural class one joined the bridge program did while others are taking classes at columbia have obtained teaching assistant positions there how much the scientific community will embrace the
label: science

description: formerly incarcerated once classes are finished is question thinks about he moves through his phd for now he focused developing the skills to become an independent researcher and hoping that if he works hard enough science will take care of the rest just keep going he says just keep going thousands of years ago near what is today the british village of heslington man body started to decompose flesh and organs became mud hair turned to dust in the end bones remained and mysteriously small piece of his brain after months of patiently investigating the tissue proteins an international team of researchers finally has clues explaining this remarkable instance of preservation and it could help us better understand how healthy and unhealthy brains actually work the discovery of the heslington
label: science

description: brain one of the oldest specimens of human neural tissue ever to be uncovered in the uk left researchers with challenging puzzle to solve within moments of typical death brain tissue starts to decompose compared with other body parts this decay is especially rapid with various proteins going to work demolishing cellular infrastructure so when archaeologists looked inside skull pulled from an iron age dig site they were understandably shocked to see the withered remains of what looked like chunk of recognisable human brain according to carbon dating the man breathed his last breath somewhere between and bce most likely the result of fractured spine the kind you get after hanging exactly who he was why he died probably won ever be known sometime after his speculated execution though the
label: science

description: victim severed head was thrown into pit where it was encased in fine grain sediment soft tissues can often be preserved if they re desiccated frozen kept in an anaerobic acidic environment what especially strange in the case of the heslington skull is the lack of preservation of any other part of the body including hair for all appearances the firm material looks like caramelised chunk of human cerebral cortex only it percent smaller than an adult human brain the heslington brain dr axel petzold to work out what made the remaining organic material so special researchers took closer look at the nature of its proteins unlike most organs the brain needs to be well supported cellular level to operate maintaining connections within the complex weave of neurons and their
label: science

description: long bodies matrix of intermediate filaments ifs performs this task in living brains and it seems under the right circumstances they can retain some kind of integrity long after the cells have been reduced to molecular ashes we already know fair bit about these ifs based various pathological studies different cell types have their own types of filament and this specificity has attracted research for uncovering biomarkers for neurological diseases in the case of the heslington brain microscopy revealed weaves of ifs that resembled the long threads of axons making up living brain only shorter and narrower while antibody markers matching axon proteins confirmed they once housed the long neuron tails further analysis with specific antibody markers revealed disproportionate amount of neural structures belonging to helper cells such astrocytes with
label: science

description: fewer proteins marking out thinking grey matter tissue determining why these particular astrocyte ifs in particular didn follow the usual path of decay was never going to be simple there were no signs of the preserving tannins often seen in british bog bodies and while the specimen ph was towards the lower end the researchers weren confident they could use it to estimate the acidity of the body grave what more proteins that stick around at relatively warm temperatures tend to form stable structures and stable proteins don unfold easily unstable ones so over the course of year the researchers patiently measured the slow unwinding and breakdown of proteins in modern specimen of neural tissue and compared it with the decay within the heslington brain the results invited speculation over
label: science

description: chemical that blocks destructive enzymes called proteases in the months following death allowing the proteins to coalesce into stable aggregates that could persist at warmer temperatures combined the data suggest that the proteases of the ancient brain might have been inhibited by an unknown compound which had diffused from the outside of the brain to the deeper structures they write in their report what seems clear is that there was nothing particularly special about this poor iron age fellow brain rather something in the environment could have inhibited the chemical processes that would ordinarily break down the protein filaments responsible for supporting the brain white matter astrocytes at least long enough for it to clump into more robust form of course with only this incredibly unique sample to study it
label: science

description: hard to draw firm conclusions but even if the proposed unknown blocker turns out to be red herring research the way that ifs form stable aggregates could inform models explaining how destructive plaques form in our brain and with possible scraps of protein being found in fossils from time to time it would be good to have sound understanding of how they might unfold to deduce their original structures the strange brain from heslington still has few things to teach us yet this research was published in link down at time of publishing faculté sciences rabat blockchain technology is very popular and fashionable in this last decade this great innovation which emerged in meknès edition marrakech edition communauté ripam honorablement invitée rencontrer sol marocain assurance maladie obligatoire ensemble étudiants université

description: discovery and invention and encouraged by increasing awareness that science is for everyone we look forward to the next years we invite you to celebrate and look forward with us the anniversary festivities thursday january with an love science pep rally from in umsu university centre the event will include time capsule prizes and treats everyone is invited to join in the fun and are encouraged to submit time capsule predictions for the future the next years of science and to share their love of science other time capsule keepsakes are welcomed the time capsule will be placed at later date in the newly developed science courtyard for rediscovery years from now in when the faculty will celebrate its centennial celebration the faculty of science successes include nobel prizes rhode
label: science

description: scholarships the establishment of the first education program campus groundbreaking cyclotron and mass spectrometry research new antibiotics and drugs satellites smart technologies and devices and much more the faculty of science with its unique and diverse departments have many proud memories and achievements to reflect it place and point in time that allows us to reflect where we ve been what we ve accomplished how we ve changed an institution and allows us to think about what are we going to do in the next years said dr stefi baum dean of science the future is closer than we think looking ahead we know connecting discovery and invention to society results in better world in the decades ahead we are driven and inspired to make an impact join the faculty
label: science
